title: Anthropogenic Obstacles to Migratory Bird Populations
contents:
hide

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE)
library(tidyverse)

# Time series packages
library(tsibble)
library(feasts)
library(fable)



Post
Data Citation: Winger BM, Weeks BC, Farnsworth A, Jones AW, Hennen M, Willard DE (2019) Nocturnal flight-calling behaviour predicts vulnerability to artificial light in migratory birds. Proceedings of the Royal Society B 286(1900): 20190364. https://doi.org/10.1098/rspb.2019.0364
Dryad Citation: Winger BM, Weeks BC, Farnsworth A, Jones AW, Hennen M, Willard DE (2019) Data from: Nocturnal flight-calling behaviour predicts vulnerability to artificial light in migratory birds. Dryad Digital Repository. https://doi.org/10.5061/dryad.8rr0498
The data tabulates instances of birds colliding with buildings in Chicago Il, and Cleveland OH. For the analysis the data was subseted to include collision data only from Chicago.
For migratory birds, collisions with buildings may be an increasing cause of mortality along the migratory flight path. I used the data from Winger et al. to see if I could establish any increasing trends or a seasonality component to building collisions. Unfortunately the data was missing values from specific months, this could be because migration does not occur at all times of the year and therefore there was no collision incidences, or because the study did not occur for other reasons during this time and therefore there is collision data missing from the dataset. I used tsibble::fill_gaps to add NAs in the time areas with no values and then subsequently replaced those values with zeros, deciding to just attribute that missing data to no incidences of migratory bird collisions with buildings outside of the migratory period.


hide

birds <- read_csv("Chicago_collision_data.csv") %>% 
  janitor::clean_names() %>% 
  filter(locality == "CHI")

birds_ts <- birds %>% 
  mutate(date = tsibble::yearmonth(date)) %>% 
  group_by(date) %>% 
  tally() %>% 
  as_tsibble(key = NULL, index = date) %>% 
  tsibble::fill_gaps()

birds_ts[is.na(birds_ts)] <- 0





hide

ggplot(data = birds_ts, aes(x = date, y = n))+
  geom_line()+
  labs(y = "Reported Incidents of Bird Collisions", 
       title = "Bird Collisions with buildings from 1976-2016")+
  theme_bw()




Figure 1: Time series analysis of the full data set. It appears either a) less data was being recorded up until ~2000 or b) as the number of buildings increased in the Chicago area the more birds collided with buildings. There does seem to be a seasonality component to the data, this would make sense, given the seasonality of migration.
Because of the increased data from 2000 - 2016, I subsetted the data for this period for an additional time series graph and seasonal plot.


hide

birds_2k <- birds %>% 
  filter(date >= as.Date("2000-01-01"))





hide

birds_2k_ts <- birds_2k %>%
  mutate(date = tsibble::yearmonth(date)) %>% 
  group_by(date) %>% 
  tally() %>% 
  as_tsibble(key = NULL, index = date) %>% 
  tsibble::fill_gaps()

birds_2k_ts[is.na(birds_2k_ts)] <- 0





hide

ggplot(data = birds_2k_ts, aes(x = date, y = n))+
  geom_line()+
  labs(y = "Bird Collisions with buildings in Chicago from 2000 - 2016")+
  theme_bw()




Figure 2: Times series analysis for the years 2000 through 2016. A much more obvious seasonal component with a smaller set of data. There seems to be less of a trend in increasing bird collisions and more of a peak in collisions occuring for some reason in ~2014.


hide

birds_2k_ts %>% 
  gg_season(y = n) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(y = "Bird Collisions with Buildlings",
       title = "Season Plot of Building Strikes by Birds")




Figure 3: Shows a migrational component of bird collisions with incidents increasing in the fall and spring when trans-continental migration is occuring.

title: Neglected Tropical Diseases in the Anthropocene
description: Relation between Deforestation and Neglected Tropical Disease incidence in Low Income, Tropical Nations.
contents:
hide knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(here) library(tidyr) library(plotly) library(viridis) library(DescTools) hide data1 <- read.csv("last_take.csv") data2 <- data1 %>% mutate(prop_tree_loss = (tree_cover_loss_ha/area_sqkm)) %>% mutate(prop_dalys = (dalys/population)) %>% mutate(area_ha = (area_sqkm * 100)) %>% mutate(tree_cover_loss = (tree_cover_loss_ha/area_ha)) %>% select(-prop_tree_loss) %>% select(-tree_cover_loss_ha) %>% select(-dalys) data3 <- data2 %>% mutate(logdalys = log(prop_dalys)) data4 <- data3 %>% mutate(log_GDP = log(GDP_capita)) data4 <- data4 %>% mutate(win_prop_tree = Winsorize(tree_cover_loss, minval = NULL, maxval = NULL, probs = c(0.00, 0.95), na.rm = TRUE, type = 9)) #data4 %>% # summarize(dalys_cor = cor(logdalys, win_prop_tree, use = "complete.obs")) data5 <- data4 %>% mutate(country_income_level = case_when(GDP_capita >= 13000 ~ "high", GDP_capita >= 4000 ~ "middle", GDP_capita <= 4000 ~ "low")) hide equLOWcountries <- c("Burundi", "Benin", "Bhangladesh", "Bolivia", "Central African Republic", "Cote d'Ivoire", "Cameroon", "Democratic Republic of Congo", "Congo", "Comoros", "Ethiopia", "Ghana", "Guinea", "Gambia", "Honduras", "Haiti", "Indonesia", "Kenya", "Cambodia", "Laos", "Liberia", "Madagascar", "Mali", "Myanmar", "Mozambique", "Mauritania", "Malawi", "Nigeria", "Nicaragua", "Phillipines", "Rwanda", "Senegal", "Sierra Leone", "El Salvador", "Eswatini", "Togo", "Tanzania", "Uganda", "Vietnam", "Zambia", "Zimbabwe") noneqLOWcountries <- c("AFG", "ARM", "BTN", "CPV", "EGY", "ERI", "FSM", "GNB", "IND", "KGZ", "LSO", "MAR", "MDA", "MNG", "NER", "NPL", "PAK", "PNG", "SDN", "SLB", "SSD", "STP", "SYR", "TCD", "TJK", "TLS", "TUN", "UKR", "UZB", "VUT") hide data6 <- data5 %>% filter(country_income_level == "low") %>% filter(!(code %in% c(noneqLOWcountries))) Post This project was started as a final project for my fall quarter final assignment in EDS 222. The dataset collated for the visualizations below was completed in EDS 222 and includes data from the World Bank (Nation GDP per capita), the Our World in Data organization (Disability adjusted life years per country), and the Global Forest Watch (tree canopy cover loss by country). Neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) are a group of ~20 conditions. They can infect the spectra of the human population with infection typically coming from the surrounding natural environment; they account for ~17% of infectious diseases in humans. Deforestation is an anthropogenic landscape phenomenon that has affected 10% of forested areas in the last decade, with a total of 411 Mha global tree cover loss. My work in EDS 222 fit a multiple linear model regression model with an OLS fit (\[ NTD_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1Deforestation_i + \beta_2GDPcapita_i + \mu_i \]) to the full dataset and to a subset of the dataset that included only tropical, low-income nations, as these nations tend to have the highest levels of NTD incidence. Even with the data subsetted for only tropical, low-income nations, the model showed a significant relationship between GDP per capita and NTD burden (p = <0.001) and in insignificant relationship between the level of deforestation and the level of NTD burden within a country (p = 0.986). With this data subset, I created interactive versions of my report graph using plotly. hide p <- data6 %>% # Reorder countries to having big bubbles on top arrange(desc(win_prop_tree)) %>% mutate(country = factor(country, country)) %>% mutate(per_dalys = (prop_dalys * 100)) %>% mutate(per_tree = win_prop_tree* 100) %>% mutate(per_dalys = round(per_dalys, 2)) %>% mutate(per_tree = round(per_tree, 2)) %>% mutate(GDP_capita = round(GDP_capita, 2)) %>% mutate(text = paste("Country: ", country, "\nPopulation (M): ", population, "\n% DALYs of Population: ", per_dalys, "\nGdp per capita: ", GDP_capita, "\n % Tree Loss of Country: ", per_tree, sep="")) %>% ggplot(aes(x=GDP_capita, y=logdalys, color = GDP_capita, size = per_tree, text=text)) + geom_point(alpha=0.7) + scale_size(range = c(1.4, 19), name="% Tree Loss") + scale_color_viridis(discrete=FALSE, guide=FALSE) + labs(x = "GDP_capita", y = "Log(Disability Adjusted Life Years - DALYs)", caption = "Color and size indicate percent tree canopy cover loss.", title = "Trends in NTD Incidence and Canopy Cover Loss in Relation \n to Country Wealth.")+ theme_bw() + theme(legend.position="none") # turn ggplot interactive with plotly pp <- ggplotly(p, tooltip="text") pp {"x":{"data":[{"x":[2423.85,698.7,2159.16,499.38,2111.03,2453.73,855.58,2365.52,515.29,3837.58,1385.26,467.07,746.83,1257.8,2020.68,461.42,3351.12,1425.11,3123.25,3914.42,3910.26,1004.91,1535.2,1563.77,1294.24,1968.57,2173.68,1323.81,497.31,830.75,772.32,450.9,293,1335.67,1572.35,768.52,1136.59,1361.7,679.76,309.05,830.02,1577.86],"y":[-6.18097461350272,-2.79829683918758,-6.5526129467686,-2.09788789290823,-2.96665369078282,-5.81359948746316,-2.56780405177687,-5.66044152639429,-3.95056977351997,-5.36104597101723,-5.16623692009307,-2.43135789826962,-3.07294252900626,-4.97027649762149,-3.17251494078314,-2.99533882249223,-5.61144942604958,-2.62099714172672,-5.60299293208703,-6.07619049472872,-6.56694218737812,-3.67567423311124,-3.76118932899913,-5.7910881877093,-5.4753288848252,-2.65086857518139,-3.43629300306619,-5.84352616926508,-3.50638130458018,-2.74174888273066,-3.97630887711873,-2.61670876067116,-2.77234793482872,-5.03617861167474,-4.80784403751942,-1.99514855149594,-2.6831421069039,-4.33783331758621,-4.70642537699207,-4.43386627324212,-2.14134438656811,-5.08258430936388],"text":["Country: Laos

to Country Wealth.","font":{"color":"rgba(0,0,0,1)","family":"","size":17.5342465753425},"x":0,"xref":"paper"},"xaxis":{"domain":[0,1],"automargin":true,"type":"linear","autorange":false,"range":[111.929,4095.491],"tickmode":"array","ticktext":["1000","2000","3000","4000"],"tickvals":[1000,2000,3000,4000],"categoryorder":"array","categoryarray":["1000","2000","3000","4000"],"nticks":null,"ticks":"outside","tickcolor":"rgba(51,51,51,1)","ticklen":3.65296803652968,"tickwidth":0.66417600664176,"showticklabels":true,"tickfont":{"color":"rgba(77,77,77,1)","family":"","size":11.689497716895},"tickangle":-0,"showline":false,"linecolor":null,"linewidth":0,"showgrid":true,"gridcolor":"rgba(235,235,235,1)","gridwidth":0.66417600664176,"zeroline":false,"anchor":"y","title":{"text":"GDP_capita","font":{"color":"rgba(0,0,0,1)","family":"","size":14.6118721461187}},"hoverformat":".2f"},"yaxis":{"domain":[0,1],"automargin":true,"type":"linear","autorange":false,"range":[-6.79553186917223,-1.76655886970184],"tickmode":"array","ticktext":["-6","-5","-4","-3","-2"],"tickvals":[-6,-5,-4,-3,-2],"categoryorder":"array","categoryarray":["-6","-5","-4","-3","-2"],"nticks":null,"ticks":"outside","tickcolor":"rgba(51,51,51,1)","ticklen":3.65296803652968,"tickwidth":0.66417600664176,"showticklabels":true,"tickfont":{"color":"rgba(77,77,77,1)","family":"","size":11.689497716895},"tickangle":-0,"showline":false,"linecolor":null,"linewidth":0,"showgrid":true,"gridcolor":"rgba(235,235,235,1)","gridwidth":0.66417600664176,"zeroline":false,"anchor":"x","title":{"text":"Log(Disability Adjusted Life Years - DALYs)","font":{"color":"rgba(0,0,0,1)","family":"","size":14.6118721461187}},"hoverformat":".2f"},"shapes":[{"type":"rect","fillcolor":"transparent","line":{"color":"rgba(51,51,51,1)","width":0.66417600664176,"linetype":"solid"},"yref":"paper","xref":"paper","x0":0,"x1":1,"y0":0,"y1":1}],"showlegend":false,"legend":{"bgcolor":"rgba(255,255,255,1)","bordercolor":"transparent","borderwidth":1.88976377952756,"font":{"color":"rgba(0,0,0,1)","family":"","size":11.689497716895}},"hovermode":"closest","barmode":"relative"},"config":{"doubleClick":"reset","modeBarButtonsToAdd":["hoverclosest","hovercompare"],"showSendToCloud":false},"source":"A","attrs":{"105e23a4cda1d":{"x":{},"y":{},"colour":{},"size":{},"text":{},"type":"scatter"}},"cur_data":"105e23a4cda1d","visdat":{"105e23a4cda1d":["function (y) ","x"]},"highlight":{"on":"plotly_click","persistent":false,"dynamic":false,"selectize":false,"opacityDim":0.2,"selected":{"opacity":1},"debounce":0},"shinyEvents":["plotly_hover","plotly_click","plotly_selected","plotly_relayout","plotly_brushed","plotly_brushing","plotly_clickannotation","plotly_doubleclick","plotly_deselect","plotly_afterplot","plotly_sunburstclick"],"base_url":"https://plot.ly"},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]} Figure 1: Shows the linear relationship between country GDP capita and country DALY incidence rate attributed to NTDs. Size of the points indicates % of canopy cover loss by country and the color represents country GDP per capita level. Click on the point to get country-level data. hide p <- data6 %>% # Reorder countries to having big bubbles on top arrange(desc(win_prop_tree)) %>% mutate(country = factor(country, country)) %>% mutate(per_dalys = (prop_dalys * 100)) %>% mutate(per_tree = win_prop_tree* 100) %>% mutate(per_dalys = round(per_dalys, 2)) %>% mutate(per_tree = round(per_tree, 2)) %>% mutate(GDP_capita = round(GDP_capita, 2)) %>% mutate(text = paste("Country: ", country, "\nPopulation (M): ", population, "\n% DALYs of Population: ", per_dalys, "\nGdp per capita: ", GDP_capita, "\n % Tree Loss of Country: ", per_tree, sep="")) %>% ggplot(aes(x=per_tree, y=logdalys, color = GDP_capita, size = logdalys, text=text)) + geom_point(alpha=0.7) + scale_size(range = c(1.4, 19), name="% Tree Loss") + labs(x = "% Canopy Cover Loss", y = "Log(Disability Adjusted Life Years - DALYs)", caption = "Color and size indicate country GDP per capita.", title = "Trends in NTD Incidence and Country Wealth in Relation \n to Canopy Cover Loss.")+ scale_color_viridis(discrete=FALSE, guide=FALSE) + theme_bw() + theme(legend.position="none") # turn ggplot interactive with plotly pp <- ggplotly(p, tooltip="text") pp {"x":{"data":[{"x":[1.5,1.5,1.5,1.5,1.12,1.01,0.94,0.93,0.88,0.72,0.67,0.65,0.58,0.52,0.51,0.46,0.43,0.4,0.38,0.37,0.23,0.22,0.22,0.22,0.2,0.19,0.19,0.17,0.16,0.13,0.11,0.1,0.07,0.07,0.04,0.04,0.02,0,0,0,0,0],"y":[-6.18097461350272,-2.79829683918758,-6.5526129467686,-2.09788789290823,-2.96665369078282,-5.81359948746316,-2.56780405177687,-5.66044152639429,-3.95056977351997,-5.36104597101723,-5.16623692009307,-2.43135789826962,-3.07294252900626,-4.97027649762149,-3.17251494078314,-2.99533882249223,-5.61144942604958,-2.62099714172672,-5.60299293208703,-6.07619049472872,-6.56694218737812,-3.67567423311124,-3.76118932899913,-5.7910881877093,-5.4753288848252,-2.65086857518139,-3.43629300306619,-5.84352616926508,-3.50638130458018,-2.74174888273066,-3.97630887711873,-2.61670876067116,-2.77234793482872,-5.03617861167474,-4.80784403751942,-1.99514855149594,-2.6831421069039,-4.33783331758621,-4.70642537699207,-4.43386627324212,-2.14134438656811,-5.08258430936388],"text":["Country: Laos

The point color shows country GDP per capita level and point size is percent NTD incidence. Click on the point to get country-level data.

title: Air Quality Variable Correlation
description: Relatedness of Air Quality variables taken in NYC
contents:
hide

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE)
library(tidyverse)
library(ggpubr)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggfortify)
library(datasets)
data("airquality")



Post
R-studio comes with a pre-loaded dataset called airquality which is a set of air quality measurements taken from New York City over the months of May to July. While this dataset is unfortunately not the most expansive, it does allow the exploration via a Principle Coordinate Analysis (PCA) into the correlation between air quality variables. Should a more rigorous dataset of air quality measurements be taken from NYC, this PCA could provide initial predictions as to what variables of air quality may be correlated or uncorrelated to each other. The results from the PCA are visualized and summarized below.


hide

aq_clean <- airquality %>% 
  drop_na() %>% 
  janitor::clean_names()





hide

aq_pca <- aq_clean %>% 
  select(ozone, solar_r, wind, temp) %>% 
  scale() %>% 
  prcomp()

#aq_pca$rotation





hide

#autoplot(aq_pca,
     #  data = aq_clean,
     #  loadings = TRUE,
     #  loadings.label = TRUE,
    #   loadings.colour = "black",
     #  loadings.label.colour = "blue",
     #  loadings.label.vjust = -0.5
     #  ) +
 # theme_minimal()





hide

labels <- c(ozone = "Ozone", solar_r = "Solar Radiation", wind = "Wind", temp = "Temperature")

loadings_df <- data.frame(aq_pca$rotation) %>%
  mutate(axis = row.names(.))
 
new_pts_df <- data.frame(aq_pca$x)
 
ggplot() +
  geom_point(data = new_pts_df, aes(x = PC1, y = PC2), color = 'deepskyblue2', alpha = .50, size = 2.5) +
  geom_segment(data = loadings_df,
               x = 0, y = 0, aes(xend = PC1, yend = PC2, group = axis),
               arrow = arrow(length = unit(.35, 'cm'))) +
  geom_text(data = loadings_df,
            aes(x = PC1, y = PC2, label = labels), vjust = 0, hjust = .2, nudge_y = 0.1) +
  theme_minimal()




Figure 1: Principle components analysis of the airquality dataset. The PCA contains for airquality variables - Wind, Solar Radiation, Temperature, and Ozone Level.
Temperature and Ozone levels are very positively correlated, so much so that the variable arrows overlap each other. This is expected as it’s known that when the temperature increases so does the Ozone level. NYC has particularly hot and humid days when the city will issue warnings for those in particularly sensitive groups to avoid the outside air and stay inside. Temperature and Ozone Level have a negative correlation to wind. It tends to be windier in NYC in the winter time when temperatures are colder and there is a lower ozone layer. Finally, Solar Radiation is correlated with neither wind nor Ozone and Temperature. If another variable was to be included in this PCA (say cloud-cover measurements) then perhaps, there would be a correlation to Solar Radiation.

title: Exclusion
description: Effects of Climate and Herbivore Exclusion on Tick Abundance.
contents:
Post
These visualizations are a continuation of the data analysis from the Tejon Ranch Exclusion Experiment (TREE) that was also seen in the ESM 244 group project Shiny App. TREE sought to experimentally understand the interactive impacts of wild ungulate removal and replacement over a climatic gradient to ecosystem structure and function. This was achieved using replicated 1 hectare exclosure treatments along a topographical gradient (see study site drawing (again), below).
One aspect of this project studied the separate and interactive impacts of climate and herbivore removal on tick abundance. Tick-borne diseases are the most common vector-borne diseases in the United States to both humans and domestic animals. The uniqueness of the tick life cycle, requiring both an on-host and off-host stage, make ticks particularly sensitive to ecosystem-level changes.
The study found that large herbivore removal increased tick abundance and that climatic context was significant to this interaction. This study (Copeland et al.) is set to be reviewed and submitted to the Journal of Ecological Applications.
Thank you to co-author’s Sam Sambado and Dr. Devyn Orr for their assistance in data cleaning and analysis for the manuscript. Thank you to Sam for her help with the figures 1 and 2 and introducing me to the ggarange (figure 1) and scale_x_discrete(labels = ) in figure 2!
TREE Study Site Schematic

hide

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE)
library(tidyverse)
library(ggpubr)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggfortify)



Figure 1


hide

Tick <- read_csv("Tejon_clean-main/data_visualizations/Viz_Tejon_MeanComparisons_Dataset.csv")

# omit 0s to make plots 
Tick_no0 <- Tick[which(Tick$total != 0),]

plot1 <- ggplot(Tick_no0, aes(x = plot, y = log(total), fill = plot))+
  geom_jitter(alpha = .15, width = .2)+
  geom_boxplot()+
  theme_bw() +
  labs(x = 'Plot', y = 'log(Total ticks) 2016 - 2019')+
  scale_fill_manual(values=c('palegreen1','palegreen3','palegreen4'))+
  guides(fill = FALSE)

site1 <-ggplot(Tick_no0, aes(x = site, y = log(total), fill = site))+
  geom_jitter(alpha = .15, width = .2)+
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_bw() +
  labs(x = 'Site', y = 'log(Total ticks) 2016 - 2019')+
  scale_fill_manual(values=c('darkorange2','gold','cadetblue3'))+
  guides(fill = FALSE)

var_plot <-ggarrange(plot1, site1)

var_plot




Figure 1: Log of Total Tick Counts separated by Exclusion Treatment and Climate. Both Exclosures (Partial and Total had greater tick abundances than the open control. The ‘Intermediate’ climate had the greatest tick abundances than the other two climatic zones. Tick abundances were greater in the absence of cattle grazing.
Figure 2


hide

Tick$month <- factor(Tick$month, 
                        levels = c('January', 'February', 'March',
                                   'April', 'May', 'June', 'July',
                                   'August', 'September', 'October',
                                   'November', 'December'))

ggplot(Tick, aes(x = site, y = log(total), fill = plot))+
  facet_wrap(~ month, ncol = 6)+
  #geom_jitter(alpha = .35, width = .2)+
  #geom_boxplot()+
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge")+
  theme_bw() +
  scale_x_discrete(labels = c('A','I','M')) +
  labs(x = 'Site', y = 'Log of tick counts (2016 - 2019)')+
  scale_fill_manual(values=c('palegreen1','palegreen3','palegreen4'))




Figure 2: Log of monthly tick counts separated by Climate zone and Exclusion Treatment. There is a component of seasonality to tick abundance with noted increases and peaks in abundance during the early spring and mid-to-late fall. This is likely due to the importance of temperature and humidity on tick activity. It’s likely that during the summer and early fall, it becomes too hot and dry for tick questing activity. They enter a behavioral diapause and are therefore not collected by drag cloths that target questing adult ticks.

title: Niche?
contents: This has been a question plaguing the EEMB first-year cohort. EEMB 509 - Introduction to Principles of Ecology and Evolution is where the topic at hand developed. The astutely observant first-years noticed the pronunciation of said “Niche” had created its own “Niches” So is it pronounced “Neech” or “Nitch”?
